title: The King's New Clothes
sentence: When he remembered that a simpleton  or one unfit for his job would be unable to see the cloth he began to worry  ~newline~  He will be best able to see how the cloth looks  ~newline~ He could not see anything on the looms for a very good reason  ~newline~ I will never tell that I could not see the stuff    Well  Sir   said one of the weavers still pretending to work  ~newline~ The Emperor soon sent another man from his court to see how the weavers were getting on  ~newline~ He could see nothing at all but the empty frames  ~newline~ However  no one shall know anything about it   And so he praised the stuff he could not see  ~newline~ Finally  the Emperor himself wished to see the costly material while it was still in the loom  ~newline~ What glorious colors   and at the same time they pointed to the empty frames  for they imagined that everyone else could see this exquisite piece of workmanship  ~newline~  I can see nothing  ~newline~ No way would he say that he could not see what two of his advisors had praised so much  ~newline~ Everyone with the Emperor now strained his or her eyes hoping to discover something on the looms  but they could see no more than the others  ~newline~ They had sixteen lights burning  so that everyone might see how anxious they were to finish the Emperor s new suit  ~newline~ The whole suit is as light as a cobweb  one might fancy one has nothing at all on  when dressed in it    Yes indeed   said all the courtiers  although not one of them could see anything of this special cloth  ~newline~ What a magnificent train there is to the mantle  and  Created for Lit Go on the web at fcit usf edu       The Emperor s New Clothes By Hans Christian Andersen how gracefully the scarf hangs   No one would admit these much admired clothes could not be seen because  in doing so  he would have been saying he was either a simpleton or unfit for his job

title: The King's New Clothes
sentence: I should like to know how the weavers are getting on with my cloth   said the Emperor to himself one day  ~newline~ When he remembered that a simpleton  or one unfit for his job would be unable to see the cloth he began to worry  ~newline~ All the people in the kingdom had heard of the wonderful cloth  ~newline~  He will be best able to see how the cloth looks  ~newline~  What can Many years ago  there was an Emperor who was so very fond of new clothes that he spent all his money on them  ~newline~ He only went out when he had the chance to show off his new clothes  ~newline~ They said that they knew how to weave cloth of the most beautiful colors and patterns  ~newline~ The clothes made from this wonderful cloth would be invisible to everyone who was unfit for the job he held  or who was very simple in character  ~newline~  These must  indeed  be splendid clothes   thought the Emperor  ~newline~ Then  they asked him whether the cloth pleased him  ~newline~  You do not say whether the cloth pleases you    Oh  it is excellent   replied the old wise man  looking at the loom through his spectacles  ~newline~ Now he wanted to know if the cloth would soon be ready  ~newline~  The cloth which the weavers are preparing is extraordinarily magnificent   The whole city was talking of the splendid cloth  which the Emperor had ordered to be woven  ~newline~ He took many officers of the court and the two honest men who had already admired the cloth  ~newline~ The cloth is charming   said he  aloud  ~newline~ Nevertheless  they all exclaimed   Oh  how beautiful   and advised his majesty to have some new clothes made from this splendid material for the parade that was planned  ~newline~ They pretended to roll the cloth off the looms  ~newline~  The Emperor s title: The King's New Clothes
sentence: I should like to know how the weavers are getting on with my cloth   said the Emperor to himself one day  ~newline~  I will send my faithful old wise man to the weavers   said the Emperor atlast  ~newline~ It was said of the Emperor   He is sitting in his wardrobe   One day  two fellows calling themselves weavers came to town  ~newline~ They said that they knew how to weave cloth of the most beautiful colors and patterns  ~newline~ I will never tell that I could not see the stuff    Well  Sir   said one of the weavers still pretending to work  ~newline~  This pattern  and the colors  yes  I will tell the Emperor without delay  how very beautiful I think them    We shall be much obliged to you   said the thieves  ~newline~  Indeed  your Imperial Majesty   he said to his emperor when he returned  ~newline~ Created for Lit Go on the web at fcit usf edu       The Emperor s New Clothes By Hans Christian Andersen  Is not the work absolutely magnificent   said the two officers of the crown  already mentioned  ~newline~  How is this   said the Emperor to himself  ~newline~ The cloth is charming   said he  aloud  ~newline~ The whole suit is as light as a cobweb  one might fancy one has nothing at all on  when dressed in it    Yes indeed   said all the courtiers  although not one of them could see anything of this special cloth  ~newline~ These are indeed royal robes    I am quite ready   said the Emperor  ~newline~  But the Emperor has nothing at all on   said a little child  ~newline~ What the child had said was whispered from one to another
